can you try replacing the `load_state()` function in sturdy/base/validator.py with?:
```python
    def load_state(self) -> None:
        """Loads the state of the validator from a file."""
        bt.logging.info("Loading validator state.")

        state_path = f"{self.config.neuron.full_path}/state.npz"

        try:
            # Load the state of the validator from file
            state = np.load(state_path)
            self.step = state["step"]
            self.scores = state["scores"]
            self.hotkeys = state["hotkeys"]
            bt.logging.info(f"Loaded state with {len(self.hotkeys)} hotkeys")
        except FileNotFoundError:
            bt.logging.info(f"No state file found at {state_path}. Starting with empty state.")
            # Initialize with default values since no state file exists
            self.step = 0
            self.scores = np.zeros(self.metagraph.n, dtype=np.float32)
            self.hotkeys = copy.deepcopy(self.metagraph.hotkeys)
```

This update modifies the incentive mechanism for miners:

- **Grouping Miners by APY** – Before scoring, miners are categorized into bins based on their APY (ranges may be determined automatically).
- **Scoring Miners** – Miners are scored based on their APYs.
- **Penalizing Similar Allocations** – Miners with similar allocations within the same APY group receive penalties.
- Additionally, a new step is introduced to disproportionately reward the top-performing miners, ensuring that the most useful outputs receive higher incentives whilst simultaneously reducing UID pressure.

Can you elaborate on this?

The curve is flat because all miners are in the same bin. Then min max scaling pushes many rewards to 0.5. Best miner gets 1. On average this produces flat curve. We need more bins and curve will get more and more exponential.

But too many bins (APY_BIN_THRESHOLD = 0.000001) or no bins would probably favor lucky predictions and would make many swings in miner positions. Eg. a bad miner could be first for 1 epoch becasue of luck, then the next epoch would be last.
I would also add that the incentive curve needs to be robust. Exponential curve is IMO useless if the top miner changes every epoch as you cannot trust his prediciton in the long term.

The thinking behind `TOP_PERFORMERS_COUNT = 10` is when making actual asset allocation decision, you want multiple suggestions so that you can take a least extreme one, like median or the most extreme one if you like. Thats why 10 is more appropriate than winners take all for this use case.
On top of this I am considering modifying the perfomer bonus logic so that the top `TOP_PERFORMERS_COUNT = 10` miners would have 4x more incentive than the next best miner.

The rest of the outputs are basically useless so - even if the incentive curve after the first 10 miners becomes flat it doesn't matter I don't think the miners need to be rewarded unless they consistently produce good outputs such that they are able to find their spots in the top 10.  Of course, would want to give some room for new competing miners to move up the ranks and try and secure their spot in the top 10 - I think an increase to the immunity period should do the trick.

To think about: maybe remove APY_BIN_THRESHOLD and use one of the functions, which allows for dynamic binning based on the data.

*qcut https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.qcut.html*
Pros:
    •    Ensures an equal number of miners (or roughly equal) per bin
    •    Automatically adapts to the data distribution

Cons:
    •    The APY range within each bin can vary significantly
    •    Can be sensitive to duplicated values (e.g. if many miners have the same APY, it might not split bins as cleanly)

*cut https://pandas.pydata.org/docs/reference/api/pandas.cut.html*

Pros:
    •    Bins are defined by fixed APY ranges, making interpretation easier
    •    Good for when you care about absolute APY thresholds

Cons:
    •    Bin sizes (number of miners per bin) can vary widely
    •    May result in empty bins if data isn’t uniformly distributed

This solution does not address the bug found by @exceptionless . 

To address it, I would remove the `TOP_PERFORMERS_COUNT` and use `apply_top_performer_bonus` function for all miners in the top bin, which could be 1 miner or N. But there should be a cap of max multiplier is 10 or something, because all miners can be in one bin. 

Better would be to use multiplier/n_miners_in_bin to normalize so if all miners are in top bin the rewards are not multiplied, but if only one miner is in top bin then the reward is big. 

This should be enough to have exponential curve and most importantly - reward miners with highest apy!

Thoughts?

hmmm @HippoHoppy  - i think i understand this now. basically if there are `N` miners in the top bin with very similar apy, and `TOP_PERFORMERS_COUNT > N` then `N - TOP_PERFORMERS_COUNT` don't receive a bonus even if they haven't been penalized for having similar allocations to other miners. Correct?

What happens in production currently is:
- all miners are in the same bin, but only the last 10 miners get reward multiplied. These are uids 99, 98, 97, because these uids are the last in the rewards matrix. 
- if the 11th miner has the same apy as 10th miner, 11th miner doesnt get the reward multiplied. Same for 12th... etc.
If you look at metagraph, miners with uids 9x, have the highest incentive and it's not because they are good 🙂
A quick fix would be to  remove`apply_top_performer_bonus` function.
My suggestion was to only apply bonus to miners in top bin or to remove the function.

ok so I think this property arising due to uid ordering itself that you stated above is not *really* an issue,  but I think the way you described it here is a good description of the issue, and a good way to tackle it.

> Better would be to use multiplier/n_miners_in_bin to normalize so if all miners are in top bin the rewards are not multiplied, but if only one miner is in top bin then the reward is big. 
> 
> This should be enough to have exponential curve and most importantly - reward miners with highest apy!
I like this.

Gm! Hope everyone had a great weekend :EmotiSmile: . 
Just wanted to share a quick update - yesterday I spent most of my time getting release 3.0.0 ready.
Much of my effort has been on migrating many components of the sn10 code to be async. `AsyncSubtensor` is very nice, so I decided it was about time we started using it.  It's also going to be used on the default miner and validator implementations to query data from the bittensor chain, both for syncing the nodes themselves as well as for pulling info for alpha token pools. Async web3 http providers will also be used to pull data from ethereum for pool data. 

The mechanisms surrounding the alpha token pools in this update are still a work in progress, but I think I've figured out how to account for alpha staking apy - it shouldn't take very long for me to get this part of the update done. Once major parts of the codebase have been refactored to become asynchronous that will be bulk of the hard stuff out of the way :).  Hoping to have everything ticked off the checklist in the PR by Monday morning ET.

git checkout main

dbmate --url "sqlite:validator_database.db" up

how often do validators send request?

The changes I made to the schemas are mainly for UX purposes when someone uses the api endpoint on a validator to request allocations from miners in the subnet (sturdy finance is using it, and we may start onboarding others to use it as well 👀 : https://discord.com/channels/799672011265015819/1217952256306057298/1360705661637492908). 
I do agree that some things may be quite unnecessary though - i.e. the `pool_model_disc` parameter in the pools models - but I mostly blame pydantic for needing this discriminator param. Without it, the  `/allocate` endpoint's input data w/ pool parameters can't automagically be converted to the right pool type (i.e. `ChainBasedPoolModel` or `BittensorAlphaTokenPool`). For more info regarding this see pydantic's docs: https://docs.pydantic.dev/latest/concepts/unions/

If you have any suggestions on how to improve things, please do feel free to create an issue and perhaps a PR! :EmotiSmile:

If you compare yield idx at time t=0, then compare it to time t=n, then you get the percentage yield within that time period.
you can use that to calculate annualized pct. yield.

so say at time t=0 the yield index is: 1024365021085256450
then at time t=5days the yield index is: 1034365021085256450 
over 5 days the lenders to that pool would have made a  (((1034365021085256450/1024365021085256450) - 1) * 100 % return
which is approx 0.976%
annualized is approx: 71.25%

messages.content:
as per the comment in the PR:
> instead of:
> ```python
> relative_diff = abs(apy - current_base_apy) / max(abs(current_base_apy), abs(apy), 1)
> ```
> we calculate it as:
> ```python
> relative_diff = float("inf") if apy == 0 else abs((current_base_apy - apy) / apy)
> ```
> as we want to compare the relative difference in reference to the apy we are *currently* examining in the loop to help determine whether if it should be in a different bin vs. that of which contains `current_base_apy`.
running this on our validator now. if it seems aight I'll merge the hotfix soon.

regarding the high apy problem - one thing I was considering was setting a minimum stake threshold for delegates - i.e. check the total nominated alpha stake a validator has when an allocation is first received from a miner and/or the total nominated alpha stake of the validator when scoring the miner. If it is below the threshold, then the alpha staking APY of the miner is considered to be `0`. thoughts?
I ll take a look.

@shr1ftyy[τ,ℶ,κ] | SN26, SN10 its sunday morning in where i live so its hard to do a proper evaluation of such a core change. Claude says that the formula would cause excessive binning, which means that "lucky miners" would be more incentivized  - meaning there would be big shifts in each epoch of the top miner positions.
So do as you think is best for the subnet

points 2, 3, and 4 are all mute, particularly because the apys are sorted when trying to assign bins to them. 1 just makes no sense lol.
We also don't want it to be "symmetric" (point 2), because if `current_base_apy >> apy` then the relative difference would be very close to but less than `1`  (and go no higher than 1) - which is what caused all the apys to be shoved into the same bin. It also makes sense to do `abs((current_base_apy - apy) / apy)` because we want to compare how much bigger `current_base_apy` is vs.  `apy`.
